abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Sector Development
            Project for Burundi were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            high, the Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in post
            conflict situations, the peace-building process is the key
            objective, while the governments’ capacity to rebuild the
            nation is usually low. Therefore, helping the government to
            generate employment and rebuild infrastructure is among the
            key priorities. To this end, the design and scope should
            focus on quick and easy implementation, with rapid and
            visible deliveries/outputs. For cost estimates, substantive
            contingency funds (in this case, costs overruns and
            financing gaps amounted for one-third of the total project
            funds) should be included together with conservative cost
            assumptions. National Roads Agency (Office des Routes), or
            OdR needs to increase its absorption capacity by improving
            its programming skills and implementing road maintenance
            works accordingly. Regarding the National Road Funds (FRN),
            its resources (the proceeds from fuel levies) should be
            directly paid on its accounts and not transit through an
            account at the treasury where it may be transferred to roads
            rehabilitation and new construction, or even used to cover
            other gaps in the country’s budget. Finally, a
            well-functioning FRN is paramount for sustainable road
            network conditions. FRN demonstrated its good performance,
            especially through the successful use of ACDs.

repnme.cdata!: Burundi - Road Sector Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Road Sector
            Development Project for Burundi is to rehabilitate selected
            priority roads, port and airport facilities of the
            Recipient; and to support the regulatory and institutional
            reform and effective management of the recipient's
            road, port and airport sectors. The proposed restructuring
            will help complete ongoing activities and implement
            remaining activities, which are critical for the attainment
            of the project development objectives (PDOs). The ratings
            for achievement of project development objectives and
            implementation performance are moderately satisfactory, as
            documented in the last archived Implementation Status
            Reports (ISRs) dated August 13, 2013. The project
            development objectives continue to be achievable. Except for
            the seven-month extension of the closing date from December
            31, 2013 to July 31, 2014, this restructuring does not
            entail any change to the overall scope of the project or the
            PDO. The entire project will be 10 years and 4 months old at
            the time of the new closing date of July 31, 2014.
